Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve overall health through on-body biomedical monitoring. Although this study focuses on a wearable textile material for use specifically in cutaneous sensing applications, these same materials will have broader implications for public health since they can be used for a variety of sensing or device applications. The materials developed in this work could be functionalized for the detection of a wide variety of biomarkers and such innovations could profoundly impact our ability to diagnosis, treat, and prevent diseases, from analysis of common diabetic neurological complications to the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). These materials could also be used in smart clothing to allow for biomonitoring in advanced prosthetic limb applications, bedridden patients, or athlete performance tracking. Development of a wearable sensing material capable of determining physiological parameters at the surface of skin could also make construction of health monitoring sensor arrays relatively easy and inexpensive.

This I-Corps project is based on innovative, textile-based sensing materials capable of continuous monitoring of biomarkers in sweat, which could have significant impact on the field of biomedical monitoring. These sensing materials would be better than current sensors as they could provide continuous information about a person's health based on a molecular level analysis of sweat biomarkers in a flexible, lightweight device that could be worn in any application without discomfort. This technology can provide reliable, real-time monitoring of dehydration (sodium ions), muscle fatigue (lactic acid), and temperature in cutaneous sweat. These sensors are made of functionalized carbon nanotube nanocomposites with an electrospun polymer base. One sensor, using a polypyrrole functionalization, has been demonstrated to measure temperature in a physiologically relevant range (25-45 degrees Celsius). Selective nanocomposite materials functionalized with calixarene can selectively measure sodium ions in synthetic sweat, without ionic interference; while, nanocomposite materials functionalized with lactate oxidase have been demonstrated to selectively measure lactic acid without glucose interference. The data collected from the developed sensor could lead to better understanding of health and disease processes, leading to better treatments and health outcomes for all patients.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF ICorps grant (1736293) was awarded in 2017 to a team from The University of Akron, consisting of PI Dr. Chelsea Monty, entrepreneurial lead (EL) Dr. Hanieh Ghadimi, and business mentor James Griggy. The major goal of this work was to perform customer discovery and market research on a wearable health sensor developed by Drs. Monty and Ghadimi.  An additional goal of the project was for Dr. Ghadimi to undergo training on Lean Launchpad business model development.

 

The initial work focused on testing the hypothesis that the technology would be of interest to NCAA trainers and coaches.  Initial interviews were conducted with NCAA strength and conditioning coaches and athletic trainers at different universities, college and athletic centers.   It was determined that the major issues for athletic trainers were athlete compliance, time management/distraction, and resources. Also, NCAA strength and conditioning coaches and athletic trainers did not list hydration as a key problem.  Therefore, the team pivoted from NCAA trainers and coaches towards age group endurance athletes interested in monitoring their hydration levels during races and training.  Subsequent interviews were then conducted with representatives from Gatorade Sports Science Institute, Adidas, Under Armour, and Fitabase (the company that does data collection and aggregation for Fitbit). In addition, many interviews were conducted at endurance events such as races/triathlons with runners, families of participants, and other booth vendors ranging from footwear technology to supplement and nutrition. 

 

Among the 340 athletes interviewed, 67% rated the technology as a ?must have? or were actively looking for this technology as a solution to a current problem.  One triathlete expressed she was worried about getting dehydrated. Even though she drinks water every 20 minutes during a race, she still said was unsure of her hydration levels and stated that knowing when to drink would be extremely helpful. Many interviews revealed that athletes were guessing their way through hydration, and risking injury and cramping if they guessed incorrectly.  Some athletes did comment that they believed that they personally were not at risk for dehydration because they could ?feel? when they needed to replenish themselves. Many consume electrolyte supplements such as gels or powders that they mix with water, and take them on a schedule throughout a race. Most athletes already wear a high-tech fitness tracker, such as the Garmin watch, but these devices do not track personalized, real-time hydration and electrolyte levels 

 

Based on the I-Corps process, an initial customer segment and business model was determined. The initial target market for commercialization is endurance athletes who are interested in monitoring their physiological data for better performance and decreased hydration related issues. The device will be able to analyze the composition of sweat that the athlete produces and send data via Bluetooth technology to the user?s smart device to recommend how much of a replenishing supplement or beverage they should ingest.  Initial interviews show that the target endurance athletes are between 18-45 years of age and their purchasing decisions are influenced by their coaches or trainers, other athletes, magazine and blog posts, and vendors at race expos.  These athletes typically spend $4,752 to 18,000/year on personal fitness technology and equipment.  Most athletes shop online or at specialty retail stores.

 

Through the NSF I-Corps program, market needs were established, potential customer and strategic partners were identified, and revenue strategies and market segments were outlined. Direct sales will be the primary revenue model; however, the team will be open to licensing and joint development.  The team estimates a price point of $100 for the device (sensor and electronics) and accompanying app. Based on performance and cost, the team may sell the sensor component as a disposable single-use piece, or as a separate piece to be replaced every three to six months, creating a recurring revenue stream. Future work will focus on app development, so that the readout of the sensor is in understandable format (i.e. ?drink 1 cup of water) and can be integrated into current smart watches and devices (i.e. Garmin watch). Additionally, the team has founded a start-up company, RooSense, to further commercialization of the technology.     

 

The broader impact of this I-Corps project is the development a new and useful diagnostic and wearable monitoring technology for consumers in health and medical professions, point-of-care users and patients, athletes and athletic trainers, and in recreational fitness.  Development of a wearable sensing material capable of determining physiological parameters at the surface of skin could make construction of health monitoring sensors relatively easy and inexpensive.  The main impact will be in the biomedical sector, where bio-based metrics have developed into their own global category of sensing technologies. As research in this area grows at a fast pace, and as technological advancements emerge in smart clothing applications, information about the market needs for athletes will help guide informed decisions for future investigators.
